topics.title: Opening: Strategy as an action agenda
topics.summary: Rumelt argues strategy should be treated as an actionable agenda, not mission/vision/values work. Start by identifying 1–2 addressable challenges and define coherent actions to tackle them.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Richard Rumelt, his books (Good Strategy Bad Strategy, The Crux), and his experience advising major companies and government organizations.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for CommandBar and Miro.

topics.title: What strategy is: overcoming high-stakes challenges
topics.summary: Rumelt defines strategy as a design (policy + action) for overcoming a high-stakes challenge, tracing the term to Greek 'strategos' and emphasizing strategy’s problem-centered nature.

topics.title: The kernel: diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent action
topics.summary: Rumelt explains his three-part 'kernel' of good strategy and contrasts it with mere analytical tools. He emphasizes rich diagnosis, choosing a real guiding policy (not many priorities), and coherent actions that don’t conflict.

topics.title: Concrete examples and why organizations fail
topics.summary: Using Microsoft’s AI pivot as a simple illustration, Rumelt notes strategy isn’t mysterious—organizational leaders often fail by assembling initiatives without synthesis or follow-through.

topics.title: Bad strategy patterns: goals, fluff, missing diagnosis
topics.summary: Rumelt outlines common bad-strategy signals: mistaking goals for strategy, word-salad fluff, incoherent actions, and especially skipping diagnosis (e.g., 'coordinate better' without addressing why coordination fails).

topics.title: Focus and the danger of too many priorities
topics.summary: They discuss why focus is the core source of strategic power and why saying yes too often dilutes a good strategy. Rumelt uses a magnifying-glass metaphor: power + focus + an affectable target.

topics.title: Power in strategy: asymmetry and advantage sources
topics.summary: Rumelt defines power as exploitable asymmetry—reputation, relationships, being first, customer access—and illustrates with IBM/Gerstner’s customer footprint as power that later became a constraint as markets shifted.

topics.title: Modern power: network effects and scale dynamics
topics.summary: Rumelt discusses network effects and user-base power across platforms (telecom, social, Amazon) and how AI may amplify scale advantages via data. He notes specialization as a way to compete against giants.

topics.title: Where power fits in the kernel and execution
topics.summary: Rumelt explains power as the reason a strategy is not an even bet—what makes success plausible versus base rates (e.g., restaurants). He critiques unfocused objectives using Afghanistan as an example of incoherent aims.

topics.title: Using history to build diagnosis and judgment
topics.summary: Rumelt argues strategy isn’t a science; it relies on analogy and historical understanding. He describes reading contemporaneous sources (e.g., 1928–29 newspapers) to practice diagnosis and offers his own hypothesis about autos and the Great Depression.

topics.title: How to write strategy: start with the challenge
topics.summary: Rumelt gives tactical guidance: explicitly state what makes the challenge hard, avoid the overloaded 'strategy' label, and write an action agenda. Start from ambitions, pick an important and addressable challenge, then list concrete action steps.
